name: Includes individuals involved in the actual administration of care. This entails doctors and their associated staff.

Describes general monitoring of current health. This may include everything from routine checkups with your primary care physician to scheduled visits to your specialist physician (e.g. therapist, OB-GYN).
Specialists focus on a subtype of medicine. Example specialties range from gynecology to mental health to oncology.
Your first point-of-contact in healthcare when it comes to regular check-ups to addressing initial health conerns. This is typically your family doctor or general practictioner.
Consists of professionals involved in prevention and treatment of diseases in your oral cavity.
Labs where clinical tests (e.g. blood work) for diagnostic purposes are performed.

Clinics that exist outside of the hospital setting. They are generally run by a handful of physicians and nurses. Such clinics include urgent care (i.e. places to treat serious (but not emergency room-required) illnesses like a cold) to fertility clinics.
Defined by short-term, often in-patient care, whereby the patient is under active monitoring by a physician.
Where emergnecy or short-term care is provided (e.g. surgeries or urgent care).
Hospitals that specialize in treatment of serious mental health disorders (e.g. schizophrenia).
Such outpatient centers provide same-day, basic surgical care (e.g. cataract surgey, colonoscopy, etc.).
Vehicalar services for transporting patients to places of care.
Nursing services in support of medical doctors providing acute care.
Defined by rehabilitation or palliative services that you'd receive afte a stay in an acute care.
Nursing services associated with post-acute care (e.g. visiting nurses, nursing homes).
Supportive care provided at home. Often for adults or seniors recovering from hospital stay.
Clinics with goal of re-integrating patient back into day-to-day life (e.g. drug rehab, psych rehab).
Clinics that provide dialysis (for patients with forms of kidney failure).
Clinics that focus on palliative care, often for terminally-ill patients.
Hospitals designed for long-term care (greater than ~25 days stay)
